title: 108_hr3972
content: The Act titled "Protecting Our Children from Violence Act of 2004" allows state social services officers access to federal databases for specific purposes. The Attorney General shall grant covered State social services officers online access to federal databases for criminal history records checks on individuals who resided with a minor. The Attorney General grants State social services officers access to federal databases for criminal history checks on individuals who resided with a minor in cases of abuse or neglect investigations. The Attorney General ensures that State social services officers have electronic access to the National Crime Information Center for missing persons checks related to investigations involving missing children. State social services officers can request assistance from law enforcement agencies to recover missing children. Covered officers must be certified by the head of a State agency and have direct involvement with minors in the child welfare system. In this section, an appropriate individual must have the authority and meet Federal standards for access, including training and certification. The term "control terminal agency" refers to a criminal justice agency with direct access to the National Crime Information Center network. The term "State" includes the District of Columbia, the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico, and any other territory or possession of the United States, providing statewide service to criminal justice users for systems managed by the FBI's Criminal Justice Information Services Division. SEC. 3. ACCESS TO III BY NATIONAL CENTER FOR MISSING AND EXPLOITED CHILDREN. The Attorney General must ensure that specific divisions of the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children have access to the Interstate Identification Index, subject to meeting Federal standards for access. SEC. 4. PRIVACY PROTECTIONS. Privacy protections are in place for information obtained through checks or access under sections 2 and 3. This information cannot be altered except for national security reasons. It can only be released to other authorized officers or employees. Any person who knowingly releases information obtained through checks or access under sections 2 and 3 in violation of the law shall face criminal penalties of up to 1 year imprisonment or fines under title 18, United States Code.
